blog.name: wholesomelightheart
blog.title: Walking in a Blur
blog.description: Kirsten | she | 21 | Dan&Phil blog

tags: place your bets on if I'll get an A in social psych
should have written my paper on dnp but it's hard to do when you're given no content to research
summary: It’s Opinionated Phannie Hours(TM) because I just took a social psych exam and I’m having a Thought Something that I wish Dan...
body:
It’s Opinionated Phannie Hours™ because I just took a social psych exam and I’m having a Thought

Something that I wish Dan (and to a lesser extent Phil) would understand is that I think for me any many others, the issue isn’t really about content of lack thereof, it’s the change in their communication and relationship with their audience.

Dan has made a point of saying that his break from YouTube is of a creative nature, like he said during that II Q&A on here: “the thing about youtube is that it never stops - as opposed to a musician’s album cycle or a tv show with seasons that has natural breaks that allow for the creator to be inspired”

That point of view is actually very true - nothing blooms all year round, it’s unrealistic to assume that a YouTuber would constantly be inspired and motivated despite the setup of the website demanding that more often than not.

If YouTube and influencers were like a musicians album cycle of a tv show, this makes sense. Here’s the big issue: YouTube and influencers are not the same as musicians or actors.

The reason I bring up that I just took a social psych exam is that this reminds me of a paper I literally just wrote about influence and why, say, Shane could so wholly convince millions of people that Chuck E Cheese recycle pizza (yes I wrote a research paper on that and yes I got an A). YouTubers differ from mainstream media in many ways, but one of their major powers that mainstream media can never truly reach is that the distance between them and us is far less, either literally or figuratively. A message or a persuasion or an influence gains a lot more power if the person giving those said things is familiar and genuine.

So I get to thinking about how Dan and Phil have historically been some of the most engaged YouTubers I’ve followed. Even little things like responding to tweets or comments or liking art - how often do you see mainstream celebrities doing that kind of thing? Not to mention liveshows where they are talking directly to people (or that hellshow called Rize where they were engaging in one-on-one interactions with audience members) or an entire worldwide tour where they also met people individually and then carried out a show based on the audience’s input - it’s called Interactive Introverts for a reason. The distance between us and them has been so small for so long.

We’ve gone from that to occasional tweets and instastories, no liveshows, Phil (bless his heart) giving us content that has grown very distant from the audience, and even worse, information being given to us through third-party sources like the companies they work with or other YouTubers?

I don’t really care that Dan isn’t making videos. I don’t really care that Dan and Phil Games is gone. What I care about is that they’re losing such a unique part of being an online influencer with a previously very engaged audience and justifying it the same way that only mainstream media can do with a marginal degree of success. It doesn’t work for Dan to say that this is similar to musicians or actors because he is neither of those things - and it’s supposed to be a good thing. I can’t think of anyone, both YouTubers and their fans, who want YouTube to become the same thing as mainstream media. In fact, we fight that routinely. It seems like Dan and Phil are giving up that fight, and, even worse, they’re doing it at the expense of millions of people who have supported them for years.

A true happy ending is that this is one of those times where Dan and Phil spend months secretly working on a project, but even then, a lot of damage has been done. A lot of trust has been lost. I just wish they’d realize that the best thing they could possibly do in this moment is talk to their audience and maintain a fraction of their positive influence on so many.
